value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">30</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But again down on the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-bank">Bankside</rs> the curtain rises.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The trumpets sound; the flag blows and the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">shadowy insubstantial life txmxmxx of Squires, nobles</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Maids of 
            <choice>
              <sic>hnour</sic>
              <corr>honour</corr>
            </choice> and country 
            <choice>
              <sic>gentlmen</sic>
              <corr>gentlemen</corr>
            </choice> is before us.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">In one second we are in the thick of love; murder; adultery.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-york" key="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</rs> is before us. There is <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-frana" key="Frankland">Frankland</rs> and his <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-franb" key="Frankland's Wife">wife</rs>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there is <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wend" key="Wendoll">Wendoll</rs> the 
            <choice>
              <sic>adulterere</sic>
              <corr>adulterer</corr>
            </choice>; and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-acto" key="Acton">Acton</rs> the villain.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Supper is laid; the cards are on the table, and next moment</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the husband throwing open the door sees his wife lying in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the arms of her lover. The yellow pages in Record offices</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and Muniments rooms 
            <choice>
              <sic>wit</sic>
              <corr>with</corr>
            </choice> their 
            <choice>
              <sic>contorsions</sic>
              <corr>contortions</corr>
            </choice>, their evasions,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">give place to outright speech. In the play 
            <choice>
              <sic>tself</sic>
              <corr>itself</corr>
            </choice> all is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">evident, 
            <choice>
              <sic>outapoken</sic>
              <corr>outspoken</corr>
            </choice>. In 
            <choice>
              <sic>r al</sic>
              <corr>real</corr>
            </choice> life all is shadowy and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">suppressed.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But by 
            <choice>
              <sic>degrrees</sic>
              <corr>degrees</corr>
            </choice> the dramatist sheds his anonymity.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He separates himself from his audience. He pauses, sometimes;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he 
            <choice>
              <sic>di erts</sic>
              <corr>diverts</corr>
            </choice> the interest from the action to the 
            <choice>
              <sic>mtove</sic>
              <corr>motive</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">motive behind the action. What, he broods in <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-woma" key="Woman Killed with Kindness, A">a Woman killed</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs>with kindness</rs>, is the effect of mercy?--- if the adulters</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are confronted not with death but with a guilty conscience?</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">As the plays come faster and faster, as the curtain rises</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">again and again, upon <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-cmar" key="Marlowe, Christopher">
            <choice>
              <sic>Marloew</sic>
              <corr>Marlowe</corr>
            </choice></rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tkyd" key="Kyd, Thomas">Kyd</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-they" key="Heywood, Thomas">Heywood</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-jmar" key="Marlowe, John">
              <choice>
                <sic>Marts n</sic>
                <corr>Marston</corr>
              </choice></rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-ctou" key="Tourneur, Cecil">Tourneur</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-jfor" key="Ford, John">Ford</rs>-- anonymity and the pressure of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">audience cease to bind the playwright. The reader loses his</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">anonymity too. He 
            <choice>
              <sic>chhoses</sic>
              <corr>chooses</corr>
            </choice>; he 
            <choice>
              <sic>discrimitaes</sic>
              <corr>discriminates</corr>
            </choice>. Here are</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>kick nacks</sic>
              <corr>knicknacks</corr>
            </choice>; curiosities; illustrations of the time. But</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">here on the other hand, what we call for short ourselves--</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the thought that we think 
            <choice>
              <sic>instcintively</sic>
              <corr>instinctively</corr>
            </choice>, the comment that</l>
